tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving finding the natural frequency of a spring-mass system. It requires understanding of multiple concepts (spring constant, mass, natural frequency) and involves a multi-step solution to determine the equivalent spring constant and then calculate the frequency. The image is essential for understanding the configuration of the springs and masses.

answer_validation.reasoning: The system consists of two equal masses m connected in series by three springs: k (left to wall), 2k (between masses), and k (right to wall). Taking rightward displacements x1 and x2 from equilibrium, the restoring forces give the equations of motion: m\ddot{x}_1 + (k+2k)x_1 - 2k x_2 = 0 and m\ddot{x}_2 + (k+2k)x_2 - 2k x_1 = 0. Thus the stiffness matrix is K = [[3k, -2k],[-2k, 3k]] and mass matrix M = mI. Natural frequencies satisfy det(K - \omega^2 M) = 0. This yields (3k - m\omega^2)^2 - (2k)^2 = 0, so 3k - m\omega^2 = \pm 2k. Hence \omega_1^2 = k/m and \omega_2^2 = 5k/m. The highest natural frequency is \omega_2 = \sqrt{5k/m}. Substituting k = 1250 N/m and m = 10 kg gives \omega_2 = \sqrt{5\times1250/10} = \sqrt{625} = 25 rad/s, matching the official key.

step_by_step: Step 1: Identify the system as a 2-DOF translational spring-mass system with two equal masses m and three springs: k to the left wall, 2k between masses, and k to the right wall.
Step 2: Choose generalized coordinates x_1 and x_2 as rightward displacements of the two masses from equilibrium.

Step 3: Write the force balance on mass 1: left spring force = -k x_1, middle spring force = -2k(x_1 - x_2). Sum gives m \ddot{x}_1 = -k x_1 - 2k(x_1 - x_2). Rearranged: m \ddot{x}_1 + 3k x_1 - 2k x_2 = 0.

Step 4: Write the force balance on mass 2: right spring force = -k x_2, middle spring force = -2k(x_2 - x_1). Sum gives m \ddot{x}_2 = -k x_2 - 2k(x_2 - x_1). Rearranged: m \ddot{x}_2 - 2k x_1 + 3k x_2 = 0.

Step 5: Express in matrix form: [M]{\ddot{x}} + [K]{x} = 0 with M = m\begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\0 & 1\end{bmatrix}, K = \begin{bmatrix}3k & -2k\\-2k & 3k\end{bmatrix}. Assume harmonic motion {x} = {X} e^{i\omega t} to obtain (K - \omega^2 M){X} = 0.
Step 6: For non-trivial {X}, set det(K - \omega^2 M) = 0: det\begin{bmatrix}3k - m\omega^2 & -2k\\-2k & 3k - m\omega^2\end{bmatrix} = 0. This gives (3k - m\omega^2)^2 - (2k)^2 = 0.

Step 7: Solve the characteristic equation: (3k - m\omega^2)^2 = 4k^2, so 3k - m\omega^2 = \pm 2k. Thus for '+' sign: 3k - m\omega^2 = 2k \Rightarrow m\omega^2 = k \Rightarrow \omega_1^2 = k/m. For 'âˆ’' sign: 3k - m\omega^2 = -2k \Rightarrow m\omega^2 = 5k \Rightarrow \omega_2^2 = 5k/m.
Step 8: Compute the higher frequency: \omega_2 = \sqrt{5k/m} = \sqrt{5\times1250/10} = \sqrt{625} = 25 rad/s (highest natural frequency).

topic.name: Vibration of multi-degree-of-freedom systems
topic.syllabus_ref: Vibration of beams and multi degree of freedom systems

essential: Free vibration of single-degree-of-freedom spring-mass systems
Hooke\'s law and spring stiffness concepts
Matrix representation of equations of motion

Main Concept: requires: Free vibration of single-degree-of-freedom spring-mass systems
requires: Matrix representation of equations of motion
enables: Analysis of higher-DOF structural vibration problems
enables: Design of vibration absorbers and tuned mass dampers

difficulty_factors: Requires correctly forming coupled equations of motion from the diagram
Needs comfort with small eigenvalue problem det(K - \omega^2 M) = 0
Algebraic manipulation of the determinant can cause mistakes

video_references.professor: Prof. S.K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Forced and free vibration of a 2-DOF, 3-spring system and determination of natural frequencies
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors for 2-DOF vibration systems and natural frequency calculation

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Free-body diagrams \u2192 Equations of motion \u2192 Matrix form \u2192 Characteristic equation \u2192 Solve for eigenvalues \u2192 Select highest frequency
key_insights: Symmetry of the system leads to a symmetric stiffness matrix, simplifying the determinant.
For equal masses, natural frequencies often appear as simple multiples of k/m.
Highest natural frequency corresponds to the larger eigenvalue of K - \omega^2 M = 0.

formulas_principles.name: SDOF free vibration equation
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to undamped single-degree-of-freedom spring-mass systems
formulas_principles.relevance: Used conceptually to extend to multiple degrees of freedom

formulas_principles.name: Matrix equation of motion for MDOF system
formulas_principles.conditions: Undamped, free vibration, linear springs and masses
formulas_principles.relevance: Core representation for deriving natural frequencies

formulas_principles.name: Characteristic equation for natural frequencies
formulas_principles.conditions: Obtained by assuming harmonic motion and non-trivial mode shapes
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly used to compute eigenvalues (\omega^2) of the system

formulas_principles.name: Natural frequency of SDOF spring-mass system
formulas_principles.relevance: Appears as one of the eigenfrequencies of the 2-DOF system

industry_examples: Vibration analysis of landing gear struts modeled as multi-mass spring systems
Design of satellite appendages (solar panels, antennas) where multiple masses are connected by flexible elements
specific_systems: Two-mass tuned vibration absorbers used in rotorcraft or turbomachinery
Simplified fuselage or wing models represented as lumped-mass spring systems
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate prediction of natural frequencies is essential to avoid resonance with engine orders, aerodynamic excitations, or ground-induced vibrations, which can lead to fatigue damage or structural failure.

common_mistakes.mistake: Writing incorrect spring forces, e.g., using 2k x_1 instead of 2k(x_1 - x_2) for the middle spring.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They forget that spring force depends on relative displacement of its two ends, not just one coordinate.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write spring extension as displacement of right end minus left end; then apply Hooke\'s law F = k(\Delta length).
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to wrong stiffness matrix and completely incorrect natural frequencies.

common_mistakes.mistake: Sign errors when forming the stiffness matrix, such as writing +2k instead of -2k in the off-diagonal terms.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Difficulty in tracking directions of forces and coordinates in coupled systems.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: After deriving equations, check symmetry: for conservative systems K should be symmetric (K_12 = K_21).
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives asymmetric K, non-physical modes, and wrong eigenvalues.

common_mistakes.mistake: Solving det(K - \omega^2 M) = 0 incorrectly, especially mishandling the square and \u00b1 cases.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Factor carefully: if you get (a - b)^2 - c^2 = 0, rewrite as (a - b - c)(a - b + c) = 0 and solve each factor separately.
common_mistakes.consequence: Missing one of the natural frequencies or getting non-physical values.

common_mistakes.mistake: Reporting the lower natural frequency instead of the highest one asked in the question.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They compute both frequencies but forget which one is requested.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline the phrase 'highest natural frequency' in the question and label \omega_1 < \omega_2 clearly in your work.
common_mistakes.consequence: Numerically reasonable but incorrect final answer.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: K matrix is like a network: diagonals are sum of springs at a mass, off-diagonals are negative shared springs.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Building stiffness matrix for multi-DOF spring-mass systems
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When converting free-body equations into matrix form

flashcards.front: For an undamped MDOF system [M]{\ddot{x}} + [K]{x} = 0, what equation gives natural frequencies?
flashcards.back: Assume {x} = {X} e^{i\omega t} to get (K - \omega^2 M){X} = 0. Non-trivial {X} requires det(K - \omega^2 M) = 0.

flashcards.front: Two equal masses m are connected by a spring 2k and each to a wall by spring k. Write the stiffness matrix K.
flashcards.back: K = \begin{bmatrix}3k & -2k\\-2k & 3k\end{bmatrix}, since each mass sees k + 2k on its diagonal and the shared spring gives -2k off-diagonals.

flashcards.front: What does the highest natural frequency physically represent in a 2-DOF system?
flashcards.back: It corresponds to the mode where masses vibrate with more rapid oscillation, typically with adjacent masses moving out of phase and higher effective stiffness.

flashcards.front: How do you ensure correct signs in the stiffness matrix for a 2-DOF spring-mass system?
flashcards.back: Derive equations from free-body diagrams, then check that K is symmetric and that each diagonal term equals the sum of connected spring stiffnesses while off-diagonals are negative shared stiffnesses.

real_world_context.application: Avoiding resonance in aircraft structures with multiple flexible components
real_world_context.industry_example: In a twin-engine aircraft, engine-induced vibrations can excite fuselage and wing modes. Engineers model these as multi-DOF systems to ensure natural frequencies do not coincide with engine orders.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If a structural mode aligns with an excitation frequency, large oscillations can cause passenger discomfort, instrument malfunction, or fatigue cracking.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a standard 2-DOF spring-mass problem: quickly write equations using symmetry, form 2x2 determinant, and solve for \omega^2. Algebra is manageable within 2-3 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, note that one frequency will be around \sqrt{k/m} and the higher one a few times larger; with k=1250, m=10, \sqrt{k/m}=~11 rad/s, so a plausible higher frequency is near 25-30 rad/s.
exam_strategy.time_management: Limit yourself to ~3 minutes. If determinant algebra is taking too long, plug in \omega^2 = k/m and 5k/m to see if they satisfy the characteristic equation, exploiting symmetry.

search_keywords: two degree of freedom spring mass system natural frequencies
mass and stiffness matrix vibration analysis
determinant K minus omega squared M

alternative_methods.name: Energy (Rayleigh-Ritz) method for 2-DOF systems
alternative_methods.description: Assume modal shapes (e.g., in-phase and out-of-phase motion) based on symmetry, compute maximum kinetic and potential energies for each assumed mode, and use T_max = U_max to find \omega for each mode.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives physical insight and can avoid determinant algebra; especially easy for symmetric systems. Cons: Requires good intuition about mode shapes and may be less straightforward for asymmetric systems.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when the system is symmetric and likely modes (in-phase, out-of-phase) are obvious, or when you want physical understanding rather than pure matrix manipulation.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Natural frequencies of flexible modes can couple with rigid-body modes, affecting flutter and dynamic stability.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Poles of a closed-loop system are analogous to natural frequencies; eigenvalue analysis is common to both.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Satellite appendages modeled as multi-DOF systems require eigenvalue analysis to design attitude control without exciting structural modes.

deeper_dive_topics: Mode shapes and orthogonality properties in multi-degree-of-freedom systems
Modal superposition method for forced vibration response
Effect of damping on coupled modes in 2-DOF systems
General eigenvalue problems in structural dynamics using finite element methods

syllabus_mapping.gate_section: Vibration of beams and multi degree of freedom systems
syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Free vibration of multi degree of freedom systems, natural frequencies and mode shapes
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question directly tests core skills in setting up and solving 2-DOF vibration problems, which are fundamental for aerospace structural dynamics.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided detailed examples of SDOF and 2-DOF vibration systems, including derivation of equations of motion, formation of mass and stiffness matrices, and solving det([K] - \omega^2[M]) = 0. While not matching the exact configuration, the methods and formulas were directly applicable to this problem.

future_questions_potential: Ask for both natural frequencies and corresponding normalized mode shapes for the same 2-DOF system.
Modify one spring stiffness and ask how the highest natural frequency changes as a function of that stiffness.
Introduce light damping on each mass and ask for approximate damped natural frequencies and modal damping ratios.
Apply a harmonic force on one mass and ask at which excitation frequencies resonance occurs and which mass responds more.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: For the system of springs and masses shown below, k = 1250 N/m and m = 10 kg. The highest natural frequency, omega, of the system is _______ radians/s (round off to the nearest integer).
